title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at UT Southwestern Medical Center (Dallas, TX) in Jul 2022
Interview Descriptions: For me, my first interview went really well. So they booked a 2nd and 3rd interview on the same day. However, I kept receiving email notifications that the second interview had been rescheduled. It was rescheduled three times before the final day. I entered the Zoom call for the final selected time and no one was present . I waited for 25 minutes and no one arrived. I emailed the host, letting him know I was on the call and wondering if he would be joining in soon or if the interview had been rescheduled. No reply. So I hung up. After a week, I receive an email informing me that the third interview has been canceled. I reached out via email to the individuals that interviewed me the first time...no response. They literally left me with no answers. At first, it bothered me because I've never experienced an interview process like that. Now I'm grateful I got to see who they really were because it shows that they definitely have bad communication skills and that would not be conducive in a work environment, especially not for a new hire. So thank God for the experience.
Interview Questions:
Tell me about yourself?
How do you measure success?
Why do you want to work for UTSW?
Talk about a time you dealt with a difficult customer? How did you solve their issue?
How soon could you start?
What's making you look for career advancement outside of your current employer?

title: Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at UT Southwestern Medical Center in Nov 2021
Interview Descriptions:
It is a good thing UT Southwestern has such an excellent reputation for science and patient care, because their hiring process is abysmal.

I applied for the position.  The next month, a recruiter contacted me and asked me to quickly gather five references ("within 24 hours").   This wasn't simply listing the references -- they require that the five references complete an online assessment.  My references moved with urgency to get this done, and I had to complete a questionnaire detailing my qualifications.  (Really, isn't this what resumes and cover letters -- both of which I'd already submitted -- are for?)

Two months went by.  Then, someone in the department I'd be working in contacted me to fill out another questionnaire ("so we learn more about you," she said).  It was very similar to the questionnaire I'd filled out two months earlier, with the recruiter.   This was an early red flag to me about the lack of communication there.

One week later, she set up an online video interview with me.  Three of us on that call, which lasted just under an hour.  Went well.  

This was followed by two more video interviews, one with other team members I"d be working with, and then a third interview with two people in another department.  They rescheduled the third interview the day it was supposed to take place -- again, expecting me to be at their beck & call.  These were your typical stilted group interviews, and most people were friendly.   On this last interview, one of the employees asked me to send him examples of my work.  I did, but never got a response.

No response after that from anybody else either, even after I sent a follow-up message.   Two months went by and the position has been filled.  

Of course I can accept that they hired somebody else.  What's hard to swallow is the unprofessionalism and zero respect for my time and energy they displayed.  They expect candidates to jump through hoops (which I really did), but then ghost you.

Throughout the whole process, there was an undercurrent of "You're privileged to get to interview with us, and you'll be lucky if we allow you to work here."  Well, no.  Just no.
Interview Questions: What is your management style?

title: Registed Nurse Interview

Interview Descriptions: The interview assesses whether you know your materials and have research experience with collaborating with researchers to help with crunching data on different softwares. Knowledge and demonstration of technical skills are very important. Showing confidence in these is key to success in the interview.
Interview Questions: How well do you know R?

title: Housekeeper Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UT Southwestern Medical Center (Dallas, TX) in Aug 2020
Interview Descriptions: After you have an over the phone interview they will set up an in person. You won’t get a call until a month later. But once you started everything is fast
Interview Questions: Why did I choose UT. ?

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at UT Southwestern Medical Center
Interview Descriptions: I only had a phone screen with a recruiter who asked extremely basic and basic interview questions. They weren't able to describe the role at all and did not follow up after the process. I find this very unprofessional and disrespectful to the candidate.
Interview Questions: What are your strengths and weaknesses?

title: RN Clinical Educator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 weeks. I interviewed at UT Southwestern Medical Center (Irving, TX) in Jul 2020
Interview Descriptions: The process was straightforward. After a couple of weeks from applying online, I was emailed a schedule of my interview. First interview is with the manager followed by the team. The second interview was a 20 minute presentation to be presented to the team. This all happened online due to the pandemic. I was contacted by the recruiter to be interviewed regarding experience and pay expectations.
Interview Questions: How would you handle a difficult class?

title: Research Technician II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UT Southwestern Medical Center (Dallas, TX) in Jun 2020
Interview Descriptions: I interviewed over zoom. There were two interviews, the first one was with the professor of the lab and was just an orientation to that lab and what they study. I was asked about prior lab experiences. The second interview was also over zoom but with 5  Research Technicians who have been working in the lab.
Interview Questions:
Describe your prior experience working in a lab.
why do you want to be a part of this lab?
tell me about yourself.

title: Unit Secretary Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at UT Southwestern Medical Center in May 2020
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and received a call the following day from a recruiter. She asked me very basic questions: Tell me about yourself, what are your strengths, where do you see yourself in 5 years. She was friendly and set up an interview with the unit manager few days after. Prior to speaking with the manager, I was requested to provide 5 references. The interview with the manager went well, he was friendly too, asked me pretty much the same questions. He asked me when I could start and said they couldn’t wait to meet me in person (Skype interview due to the pandemic). When I asked the next step in the process, he told me to reach out to the recruiter, who would send me paperwork for me to complete. I emailed her, twice, never got a response. Fortunately, I was in the process with another hospital and got an offer somewhere else. I just find it very unprofessional to be left without answer, even if it seems to be common in the hiring process world. Employers tend to forget that we, candidates, have a lot of opportunities, there is lots of competition on the market for us as well, and they are not the only ones. Don’t make candidates believe they got a position if you are just going to ghost them. Especially during a pandemic, when lots of people are struggling, and having a job is their biggest hope to keep providing for their families.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself?

title: Financial Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UT Southwestern Medical Center (Dallas, TX) in May 2020

Interview Questions: Q: A project that you took charge of and was most proud of.

title: Ambulatory Access Center Interview

Interview Questions: Why do you think you are most qualified for this job?

title: Project Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at UT Southwestern Medical Center (Dallas, TX)
Interview Descriptions:
I applied late last year, received an interview invite about a month later, and had the in-person interview about a week after the invite. I should mention that I received a request for references after confirming the in-person interview with a requirement that my references complete an assessment of me within within 24 hours. I though this was strange since I hadn't even interviewed yet, but I contacted the FIVE people they requested and asked for my references to complete the online assessment as soon as they could. I was scheduled to meet with two people. The manager who was over the position I applied for and then the department administrator. I arrived early, checked in with the receptionist and then sat and waited for 15 minutes after the interview start time as the manager searched for an empty room and waited to see if the administrator would be joining us.

My time with the manager was pleasant for the most part. They walked me through the duties and we had a good conversation about my experience and what their expectations were for the position. They seemed interested, but mentioned that I would need to speak with the administrator before continuing to the next step. I should mention that the administrator was not present at all during the first 45 minutes of the interview and the manager had to go see if they were available and planning to join the scheduled interview. Once the administrator joined in, everything went downhill. I have encountered mean-spirited rude people in the workplace before, but most are smart enough to hide it in the interview phase when trying to recruit new talent. 

The administrator was icy and prickly as soon as they saw me (I definitely didn't fit in "racially"). They sat down and asked me to go over my experience. I started to speak when I was rudely interrupted by the administrator who huffed and told me to hurry up since it was the end of the day and they had other duties to attend to. This was baffling since I was given limited dates to choose from, with most of the dates being at the end of the week and after 1pm. I kept my composure and continued on when I was interrupted again by the administrator. This time they told me that to be transparent, they had already found the person they wanted  and were planning on going with them since they had 5+ years of experience and it would not be fair to take the opportunity away from them to give to me. I was dumbfounded. The position I had applied for was an ENTRY-LEVEL position that required at least 1 year of experience, which I had. There were other open PC  positions that required 3+ years of experience so it was extremely strange that they were knowingly placing a mid-level applicant in an entry-level position.

After that comment, I shut down. The administrator continued to prod and ask me if I had any questions. I said no. They continued to ask and seemed a bit perturbed that I didn't want to continue with the farce of an interview. I should mention that during this time the manager was sitting meekly and quietly staring at the table. They did not interject at any point or try to speak up on my behalf.  This was all I needed to know about the department and I was not interested in dealing with a meek manager and a terror of an administrator.

One of the most demoralizing interviews I have had to date, but I am glad that the administrator showed their "everyday" nature in the interview because it made the decision of steering clear of UTSW very easy. If you can act like that during an interview, how are you during the day to day? The one positive was that they validated my parking so that I didn't have to spend $2 leaving this bullying session. Complete waste of PTO for me and the time my 5 references spent filling out assessments.
Interview Questions: Mainly behavioral questions and a review of my resume/experience.

It is obvious that all persons involved were very busy but they each took time to speak with me as a prospective team member.

Three weeks later I was contacted for an interview.  I completed the interview and did well as even the interviewer was very open about my skills and the alignment.  Radio silence for two weeks.  I emailed the person who set up the interview.  Radio silence.  Four weeks after the interview, I get a generic we are moving in another direction.  Shame on your UTSW - executives deserve better.
